MiddleEarth Class Reference

A 2D array representing the cities in MiddleEarth and processes the data contained therein. More...

Detailed Description

A 2D array representing the cities in MiddleEarth and processes the data contained therein.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

MiddleEarth::MiddleEarth ( int  xsize,
int  ysize,
int  numcities,
int  seed 
)

Constructor for Middle-Earth.

Constructs a 2-d array representing Middle-Earth based on parameters

Parameters:
xsize Defines row dimension for 2-d array
ysize Defines column dimension for 2-d array
numcities Defines the number of cities to be entered into the 2-d array
seed Defines the seed for the random number generator
Note:
There cannot be more than 33 cities specified.

MiddleEarth::~MiddleEarth (  ) 

Destructor for Middle-Earth.

Deletes the 2-d array representing Middle-Earth

Member Function Documentation

void MiddleEarth::print (  ) 

Prints out info on the created 'world'.

Prints out the number of the number of possible cities to choose from and the number of cities chosen
In addition, prints out the cities themselves

Returns:
void

void MiddleEarth::printTable (  ) 

Prints a tab-separated table of the distances.

Note:
This can be loaded into Excel or similar spreadsheet program
Returns:
void

float MiddleEarth::getDistance ( string  city1,
string  city2 
)

Returns the distance between the two passed cities.

Note:
If we assume that the hash table (i.e. the map) is O(1), then this method call is also O(1)
Returns:
A float representing the distance between the cities

vector< string > MiddleEarth::getItinerary ( unsigned int  length  ) 

Returns the list of cities to travel to.

The first city is the original start point as well as the end point.

Note:
The number of cities passed in does not include this start/end point (so there will be length+1 entries in the returned vector).
Returns:
A vector of string representing the cities
